misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay aligned after sorting one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they sort the `scores` array, the corresponding `names` array will somehow stay matched up (or that `a[n-1]` will refer to the name that belongs to the highest score after sorting).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(b)` only rearranges the elements inside array `b`. It does not know that `a` is “paired” with `b`, and it will not reorder `a` to keep name–score relationships intact. Parallel arrays require you to swap elements in *both* arrays whenever you change the order, or you must sort a combined structure (e.g., objects, indices).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed name may not be the student who actually has the highest score (the score printed is the highest, but the name is just the last name entered).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Last position implies 'top student' even when order changes
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that `a[n-1]` is the top student once the scores are sorted, as if the 'top' position is a shared concept across both arrays regardless of how each array was modified.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Array indices refer to positions within a specific array, not to an abstract 'student record.' After sorting `b`, the meaning of index `n-1` in `b` changes (it becomes the largest score), but the meaning of index `n-1` in `a` does not change (it remains the last-entered name). Java does not link indices across separate arrays.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output / mismatched pair (name doesn’t belong to printed score).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Array Sorting Without Index Tracking
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they sort the scores array using Arrays.sort(b), the names array will automatically stay synchronized with the scores array. They think the computer understands that these arrays are 'paired' and will keep the corresponding name-score relationships intact.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student has not realized that Arrays.sort() only sorts the array it is given. It does not know about the parallel names array and cannot maintain the correspondence between names and scores. When scores are rearranged, the names array remains in its original order. The student's mental model treats parallel arrays as if they have an implicit link, but Java arrays are completely independent data structures.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - the program will print the name of the last student in the original input order paired with the highest score, not the name of the student who actually achieved that score.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that index [n-1] will give them the highest score after sorting, and that the name at index [n-1] in the original array will be the correct match. They think positions in arrays correspond to positions in other arrays even after one array has been sorted.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: After calling Arrays.sort(b), the element at index [n-1] is indeed the highest score (since it sorts in ascending order). However, the names array has never been sorted, so a[n-1] still refers to the last name in the original input order (Charlie), not the name of the student with the highest score. The student has confused array indices—they assume that because both arrays have the same length and started with paired data, the indices will remain synchronized after a sorting operation on just one array.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - for the sample input, the program will output 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)', because Charlie is at index 2 in the names array and 92 is at index 2 in the sorted scores array, but they are not paired.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that since names and scores were entered at the same index position (i), the computer understands they are permanently linked as a single record. Therefore, sorting the scores array will automatically rearrange the names array to maintain those associations.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects in memory. The relationship between 'a[i]' and 'b[i]' exists only in the programmer's logic during the input phase. The 'Arrays.sort()' method only has access to the specific array passed to it and cannot 'see' or modify other arrays that the programmer intended to be parallel.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the highest value in a dataset will always be located at the last index (n-1) of all related arrays after a sort operation is performed on just one of them.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to realize that sorting 'b' changes the index of the scores, while the indices of the names in 'a' remain in their original input order. This results in the program printing the last name entered in the input sequence paired with the highest numerical score, regardless of who actually earned that score.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay aligned after sorting one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they sort the `scores` array, the corresponding `names` array will somehow stay matched to those scores, so `a[n-1]` will be the name of the student who got `b[n-1]`.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(b)` only reorders the elements inside the `b` array. It does not (and cannot) automatically rearrange a separate array (`a`) to keep “pairings” intact. Parallel arrays require you to manually swap both arrays together during sorting, or to use a single combined structure (like a `Student` object) so that one sort operation moves name+score together.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (prints the highest score correctly, but often prints the wrong student name for that score).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Index-based ‘top student’ assumption without tracking movement
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that after sorting, taking the last index (`n-1`) in each array will refer to the same student, because ‘last index means top’.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: It’s true that after sorting `b` ascending, `b[n-1]` is the maximum score. But `a[n-1]` is just the last-entered name, not the name attached to the maximum score—unless the name array was rearranged in the same way as the score array. Java does not preserve cross-array relationships unless you explicitly code that relationship.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (top score correct; associated name incorrect).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they sort the scores array using Arrays.sort(), the relationship between each name and its corresponding score will somehow remain intact. They think they can safely retrieve the highest score and its associated name by accessing the last index of both arrays.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that Arrays.sort(b) only reorders the scores array. It does not reorder the names array. After sorting, the correspondence between names[i] and scores[i] is broken. Index 0 in the names array no longer corresponds to index 0 in the scores array. When both arrays need to represent paired data, they must be kept in parallel alignment—any reordering of one must be mirrored in the other. The student needs either: (1) to track which names correspond to which sorted scores using an index array, (2) to sort the names array using the same permutation, or (3) to use a data structure that keeps name-score pairs together (like a Comparator with a custom class).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The program outputs 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)' because after sorting the scores to [78, 85, 92], the names array is still ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie'], so a[2] is 'Charlie' rather than 'Bob'.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if two arrays are populated in a parallel fashion (where index i in one relates to index i in the other), sorting one array will automatically reorder the elements of the second array to maintain that relationship.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects in memory. The 'parallel' relationship exists only in the programmer's logic, not in the execution environment. Using a library method like Arrays.sort() on one array has no side effects on any other array, meaning the original indexing link is broken as soon as one array is reordered.
